lexUnit.name: excite.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: cause strong feelings of enthusiasm and eagerness in

sentence.text: As he has been discovering , the issues which excite New Yorkers are not rising levels of crime , poverty and the deteriorating quality of life .
The two lovers who excited him with their performance were both young KGB officers .
It excited her to feel a man like him shudder as he pressed himself against her , to feel his weakness underneath all that Parisian aplomb .
After Maman went away it excited her to hurt somebody .
He wanted to live , he 'd put in long years , he 'd been champion three times , it no longer excited him to race , this was it , goodbye and thanks .
However , the ` top title " promotion failed to excite booksellers .
But all that controversy on television failed to excite the public .
With earache children may screech out , can not keep still with the pain and may be violently excited by it .
And I was excited by my new importance .
Theresa was excited by the news and told Maureen that she had sent Eileen two tablets of scented soap and a box of dusting powder with a swansdown puff .
If Gould was excited by these discoveries , we hear nothing of it .
Somehow , rubbish did n't excite him any more .
Images from that trip still excited me as I contemplated my journey into the Sacred Valley and to Machu Picchu .
` I want to challenge and excite as much as I can but I 'm not going to create a work for the Scottish Ballet that is going to drive their audience away . "

Remember that anything which excites and interests you is a possibility and the greater the contrast with your first classical choice , the better you will enable the panel to see your present range .
